definitions.definition: a part of something where two or more sides, lines or edges join

examples.text: the four corners of a square
I hit my knee on the corner of the table.
Write your address in the **top** right-hand **corner** of the letter.
the left/right corner
the north-west/north-east/south-east/south-west corner
A smile lifted the corner of his mouth.
a speck of dirt in the corner of her eye
He scored with a shot into the **bottom corner** of the goal.
She tucked the ball into the corner of the net.
He parked in the far corner of the car park.
Smooth rounded corners make cleaning easier.
the four corners of his bed

definitions.definition: with the number of corners mentioned; involving the number of groups mentioned

examples.text: a three-cornered hat
a three-cornered fight

definitions.definition: the place inside a room or a box where two sides join; the area around this place
definitions.sensetop: in the cornerin the corner of something

examples.text: A large desk occupies another **corner of the room**.
He found a quiet corner and got on with his work.
They made straight for the table in the corner.
She spotted him sitting in the corner of the cafe.
We found an empty booth in a **dark corner** of the restaurant.
There was a television in the **far corner** of the bedroom.
a corner table/seat/cupboard
He took a seat in the far corner of the cafe.
Make sure the staircase is well lit, with no awkward corners.
She sat in a dark corner of the room.
She tucked herself away in a corner and read all day.
The box had been tucked away in an odd corner of the attic.
The waiter led us to a corner table.
They chose a table right in the corner of the restaurant.

definitions.definition: a place where two streets join
definitions.sensetop: corner of A and Bon the corneron the corner of somethingat the corner (of something)around/round the corneraround/round the corner from something(at the) corner with something

examples.text: The wind hit him as he **turned the corner**.
the last house before the corner of Beach Road and Hill Avenue
There was a group of youths standing on the **street corner**.
There’s a hotel on the corner of my street.
Turn right at the corner of Sunset and Crescent Heights Boulevards.
The bus stop is around the corner, I think.
the bookshop around the corner from our hotel
the big tree at the corner with Hill Street
the bank on the corner of Mount Street
at the corner of West Street and Park Street
Turn right at the first corner.
There were a lot of young men hanging about on street corners.

definitions.definition: a sharp bend in a road

examples.text: The car was taking the corners too fast.
I hate coming out of that lane because it's a blind corner.
It's a rather sharp corner and she took it a little too fast.
As they turned the corner all the bags slid to one side.

definitions.definition: a region or an area of a place (sometimes used for one that is far away or difficult to reach)

examples.text: She lives in a quiet corner of rural Yorkshire.
Students come here **from the four corners** of the world.
He knew every corner of the old town.
Welcome to our little corner of Philadelphia.
a cool shady corner of the garden
a remote corner of Afghanistan
He pushed the thought back into the darkest corner of his mind.
to **back/drive/force somebody into a corner**
They had got her in a corner, and there wasn't much she could do about it.
He was used to talking his way out of **tight corners**.
It is important to avoid being pushed into a corner.
He had her backed into a corner a couple of times with new facts she didn't know.
I'm in a bit of a corner over finding staff for Friday evening.
He was used to having to talk his way out of tight corners.

definitions.definition: a free kick or hit that you take from the corner of your opponent’s end of the field

examples.text: Moore took the corner.
The referee awarded a corner.
Sancho took the corner and Kane headed it into the net.
She put the goalkeeper under pressure and managed to force a corner.
James blocked the shot but conceded a corner.

definitions.definition: any of the four corners of a ring; the supporters who help in the corner

examples.text: Her house is just around the corner.
There were good times around the corner *(= they would soon come)*.

definitions.definition: to support and encourage somebody; to have somebody who supports and encourages you

examples.text: He's been in my corner all these years and I can never thank him enough.

definitions.definition: to go across the corner of an area and not around the sides of it, because it is quicker

examples.text: There’s a worn patch on the grass because everyone cuts (off) the corner.

definitions.definition: to do something in the easiest, cheapest or quickest way, often by ignoring rules or leaving something out

examples.text: To be competitive, they paid low wages and cut corners on health and safety.

definitions.definition: to defend your/somebody’s position against other people

examples.text: She's always had a soft corner for you.
The captain's knee injury leaves the team in a tight corner.
She’ll always help if you’re in a tight spot.
This could put the banks in a corner.

definitions.definition: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it

examples.text: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

definitions.definition: to pass a very important point in an illness or a difficult situation and begin to improve

examples.text: The country's economy has finally turned the corner.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, based on Latin cornu ‘horn, tip, corner’.
